Well... how should I put it? The immersion wasn't that strong. Sure, cutting down the small fries felt satisfying, but the boss fights gave me a bit of an odd vibe. Also, when we returned to the police station, I really wished that part had been longerâ€”itâ€™s pure nostalgia for us veteran players. That said, the Tyrant segment was pretty solid. The Tyrant is still the Tyrant, but Leon isn't the same Leon anymore. The axe parry mechanic this time is really well done. Unlike in RE4, there's no parry promptâ€”it's all up to the player's reflexes. I really appreciated that (Iâ€™ve dabbled a bit in Souls-like games myself). But itâ€™s pretty obvious you guys took some pointers from Miyazakiâ€”seriously, "We cannot open this from this side"? Classic. Hope the DLC brings something truly epic. Ideally, give Leon a longer solo adventure in Raccoon City. There weren't many returning classic characters, but the optimization was top-tier as always. Thatâ€™s all I wanted to say.

This is the first negative review I've left on Steam in a long time. This has nothing to do with the quality of the game, as I haven't been able to play it at all. Why does a game that I pre-ordered and even bought the deluxe edition of have so many system errors at the very beginning? Regardless of whether it's due to bugs or Denuvo encryption, as a long-time Resident Evil fan, CAPCOM never disappoints in disappointing people.

â‘ The whole game leaked before release, jumping in feels all over the place. The way Leon goes to the sanatorium without saving the nurse, and the setup with the magic chainsaw, had me laughing out loud.  

The chainsaw spins crazy fast on the floor, and American super-agent Leon canâ€™t even pick it up for half a day. Then a mutant zombie walks over and the chainsaw automatically sticks to its handâ€”like, okay, sure.  
After Leon uses the chainsaw, he just throws it on the ground without turning it off. Is that normal human behavior? Then it spins on the floor again, squeaking, like itâ€™s saying, 'Hey zombie bros and sisters, come get me and slash Leon .'  
I ran into this dumb setup just over an hour into the game. Itâ€™s enough to make a veteran Resident Evil player laugh in anger. Game designers, what were you thinking? Did you catch the G-virus after finishing Resident Evil 4 Remake or something?

â‘¡ Complaining about details while playing:  
Grace is portrayed as the most cowardly character in the Resident Evil seriesâ€”okay, fine, no problem. But just look at the painfully awkward lines they wrote for her. As an adult and an FBI agent, she canâ€™t even finish a sentence properly. Her speech is full of â€˜umâ€™ and â€˜uh,â€™ always hesitant, flustered, and totally illogical. The character design has zero charm or vitality.  

In the sanitarium, you upgrade the wristband from level one to level two, and I get the puzzle logic. But in the end, it makes players run around in circles just to revive a test subject and have its level-two wristband fall off?! Grace, youâ€™re an FBI agent who can shoot and make simple knivesâ€”why not just cut the strap controlling the test subject  corpse with a knife??? Looking back, the whole puzzle process feels overly complicated and doesnâ€™t hold up to scrutiny, like it exists just for the sake of a puzzle.  

When unlocking the Moon and Sun toolboxes, Braille is clearly printed on them. Why canâ€™t we just compare the Braille on the first two boxes to unlock the third Star toolbox? A respectable FBI agent like Grace canâ€™t handle this logic problem? Just because she canâ€™t read Braille, the game forces you to rescue Emily with three random Braille words for Star, Sun, and Moonâ€”itâ€™s utterly pointless, like youâ€™re pulling stuff out of nowhere. Itâ€™s the same issue as before: puzzles exist just for the sake of puzzles. The design is clunky and logically flawed. Even if saving Emily is essential for the story, couldnâ€™t there have been a better reason? The gameâ€™s writing and level design are seriously problematic.

â‘¢ The game alternates between Grace and Leon, and can roughly be summed up as 'sh*t and chocolate':  
Grace puzzles for two hours feel like eating sh*t, with clichÃ©d, long, and boring puzzle-solving, running around the maps until you feel sick, all while enduring Graceâ€™s constant shouting;  
Leonâ€™s sequences are like a three-minute hack-and-slash, with plenty of melee skills, satisfying gunplay, and ammunition, advancing a small bit of the story, like being given a piece of delicious chocolate, then switching back to Grace to eat sh*t.  

This installment made players expect too much, but the actual gameplay experience is disappointing.
